X.T: Quantum Country
Learning From Examples Using Quantum Annealing (Google Workshop on Quantum Biology)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This talk spends more time on explaining that machine learning from samples is an optimisation issue, than describing how the algorithm is implemented on D-Wave chip.

X.T: John Preskill: Quantum Computing and the Entanglement Frontier

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to build a quantum computer and how to deal with quantum entanglement.

X.T: The Mathematics of Quantum Computers | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic introduction to quantum computers.

X.T: Les Ordinateurs Quantiques

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Another introduction to quantum computers.

X.T: Trajectoires #11 - Novembre 2017 - « Informatique Quantique », avec Guillaume Aubrun

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about quantum computing and some counterintuitive properties of high dimensional space.

X.T: Graduate Student Solves Quantum Verification Problem
X.ST: Urmila Mahadev spent eight years in graduate school solving one of the most basic questions in quantum computation: How do you know whether a quantum computer has done anything quantum at all?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: UrmilaMahadev has designed a protocol to verify, with a classical computer, that a quantum computer has really performed what it is assumed to do.

X.T: The Case Against Quantum Computing
X.ST: The proposed strategy relies on manipulating with high precision an unimaginably huge number of variables

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very pessimistic view of the future of quantum computing: building a quantum computing able to perform interesting calculations is impossible because too complex.

X.T: Computer Scientists Expand the Frontier of Verifiable Knowledge
X.ST: The universe of problems that a computer can check has grown. The researchers’ secret ingredient? Quantum entanglement.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using entanglement allows to efficiently verify even more complex problems.

X.T: L’ordinateur quantique devient un enjeu politique
X.ST: Depuis plus de vingt ans, l’idée d’ordinateurs opérant sur des bits quantiques et non classiques, qui permettraient de faire des calculs aujourd’hui impossibles, stimule les imaginations et les recherches. S’est-on rapproché de l’objectif ? Le point avec Pascale Senellart-Mardon, physicienne à la frontière de la recherche fondamentale et de la technologie.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An interview of PascaleSenellart-Mardon who works on building an optical quantum computer.

X.T: Quantum Supremacy Is Coming: Here’s What You Should Know
X.ST: Researchers are getting close to building a quantum computer that can perform tasks a classical computer can’t. Here’s what the milestone will mean.

X.T: La suprématie quantique est-elle pour bientôt ?
X.ST: Selon un article publié récemment – et rapidement supprimé –, des chercheurs de Google auraient atteint la « suprématie quantique », c’est-à-dire mis au point un ordinateur quantique capable d’exécuter des tâches qu’un ordinateur classique ne pourra jamais accomplir. L’annonce était peut-être prématurée, mais ce n’est sans doute qu’une question de temps avant que cette limite ne soit atteinte. Le point sur cette question.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of quantum supremacy.

X.T: Why I Called It ‘Quantum Supremacy’
X.ST: Researchers finally seem to have a quantum computer that can outperform a classical computer. But what does that really mean?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JohnPreskill explains why he coined the term "quantum supremacy" and comments Google achievement.

X.T: La Suprématie Quantique de Google

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Google’s achievement.

X.T: La course aux bits quantiques
X.ST: L’ordinateur quantique ne deviendra une réalité qu’après la mise au point de bits quantiques performants, rapides, robustes et intégrables à grande échelle. Plusieurs candidats sont en lice. Sans compter les outsiders surgis du diable vauvert.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the current quantum computer technologies.

X.T: IBM now has 18 quantum computers in its fleet of weird machines
X.ST: That's actually a lot given how expensive, finicky and complex quantum computers are.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about IBM current status on quantum computing.

X.T: Honeywell Claims It Has Most Powerful Quantum Computer
X.ST: 6-qubit ion trap system hits a critical benchmark

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Quantum Computing: Top Players 2021

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of the quantum computer technologies and some companies using each one.

X.T: Google tries out error correction on its quantum processor
X.ST: Two options for error correction both work, but current hardware limits them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The error correction mechanisms are not really described, but it is clear that we are very far from having reliable quantum computations.

X.T: Major Quantum Computing Strategy Suffers Serious Setbacks
X.ST: So-called topological quantum computing would avoid many of the problems that stand in the way of full-scale quantum computers. But high-profile missteps have led some experts to question whether the field is fooling itself.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some people have great expectations on building a quantum computer with Majorana zero-mode quasiparticles, but experimentations still fail to detect them.

X.T: Superposition in Quantum Computers - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is motly about harmonics, there is nothing about quantum computers.

X.T: How Quantum Computers Will Correct Their Errors
X.ST: Quantum bits are fussy and fragile. Useful quantum computers will need to use an error-correction technique like the one that was recently demonstrated on a real machine.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some researchers have implemented Bacon-Shor error correction.

X.T: IBM clears the 100-qubit mark with its new processor
X.ST: Company says it's on track for 1,000+ qubits, useful computations in 2023.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM announced a quantum processor with 127 functional qubits.

X.T: Math may have caught up with Google’s quantum-supremacy claims
X.ST: But, given the rapidly evolving quantum computing landscape, that may not matter.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Researchers found an algorithm to compute the problem used by Google to declare quantum supremacy, in realistic time on a traditional computer.

X.T: Microsoft announces progress on a completely new type of qubit
X.ST: Topological qubits don't exist yet, but the company is convinced they'll scale.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Microsoft is betting on the technology of topological qubits.

X.T: The Quantum Hype Bubble Is About To Burst

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: IBM pushes qubit count over 400 with new processor
X.ST: Milestone is important for the company's road map, less critical for performance.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM delivered the planned CPU, but this one is not fully usable because the error rate is still much too high.

X.T: Google’s Sycamore chip: no wormholes, no superfast classical simulation either

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Debunking what many journalists wrote about researchers having created a holographic wormhole.

X.T: What are companies doing with D-Wave’s quantum hardware?
X.ST: D-Wave's computers are especially good at solving optimization problems.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two examples of using D-Wave quantum annealer.

X.T: Google’s improved quantum processor good enough for error correction
X.ST: The good news? It works. The bad news? It needs a lot of qubits.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google analysed the impact of using more hardware qubits per logical qubits: the error rate is marginally lower. We are still far from being able to perform real computations.

X.T: IBM compensates for errors, gets usable results out of quantum processor
X.ST: May be a way to squeeze useful work out before we get quantum error correction.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: IBM uses classical computers to mitigate errors.

X.T: Intel to start shipping a quantum processor
X.ST: The 12-qubit device will go out to a few academic research labs.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Intel will work with some universities to improve its first quantum chip.

X.T: Quantum Computing’s Hard, Cold Reality Check
X.ST: Hype is everywhere, skeptics say, and practical applications are still far away

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: L’ordinateur quantique français enfin prêt ? REPORTAGE dans la start-up française Quandela

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic presentation of quantum computing and Quandela’s technology.

X.T: What Is the True Promise of Quantum Computing?
X.ST: Despite the hype, it’s been surprisingly challenging to find quantum algorithms that outperform classical ones. In this episode, Ewin Tang discusses her pioneering work in “dequantizing” quantum algorithms — and what it means for the future of quantum computing.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: EwinTang has been able to challenge some claims that quantum algorithms are better than classical ones by improving these last ones.

X.T: But what is quantum computing? (Grover's Algorithm)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of LovGrover’s algorithm.

X.T: Where my explanation of Grover’s algorithm failed

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some clarification about the previous video.

X.T: New Quantum Algorithm Factors Numbers With One Qubit
X.ST: The catch: It would require the energy of a few medium-size stars.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title and subtitle say it all.

X.T: Quantum computing for the very curious

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good, sometimes verbose, introduction to quantum computing.

X.T: How the quantum search algorithm works

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of LovGrover’s algorithm.

X.T: How to Break Cryptography | Infinite Series

X.T: Hacking at Quantum Speed with Shor's Algorithm | Infinite Series

X.T: How Shor's Algorithm Factors 314191

X.T: Exposing Why Quantum Computers Are Already A Threat

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Still the same story.

X.T: Thirty Years Later, a Speed Boost for Quantum Factoring
X.ST: Shor’s algorithm will enable future quantum computers to factor large numbers quickly, undermining many online security protocols. Now a researcher has shown how to do it even faster.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.
